questions.text: The most common childhood tumour metastasising to the bones is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neuroblastoma is the most common pediatric tumour that metastasises to bone, especially in children under 5 years of age.

  • It originates from neural crest cells and commonly arises from the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia.
  • Bone metastases in neuroblastoma are often osteolytic and may cause bone pain, swelling, or pathologic fractures.
  • Skull and orbital metastases can result in characteristic features like raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymosis).

Explanation of other options:

Wilms' tumour (Option B): Common renal tumour in children, but less commonly metastasises to bone.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option C): Primary bone tumour in children, not a metastatic lesion.

Ganglioneuroma (Option D): Benign tumour of sympathetic origin, rarely metastasises.

Key Takeaway:

Neuroblastoma is the most frequent childhood malignancy that metastasises to bones, especially the skull and long bones.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with sudden right shoulder pain after a minor fall while playing cricket. He has no significant past medical history. On examination, mild swelling and tenderness are noted over the proximal humerus, but there is no deformity. An X-ray is taken, which shows a well-defined radiolucent lesion in the proximal humeral metaphysis with a small cortical fragment lying dependently within the cyst cavity.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a well-defined radiolucent lesion with a cortical bone fragment lying dependently within the cyst is diagnostic of a simple bone cyst (fallen fragment sign).

  • Simple bone cysts (UBCs) are serous fluid-filled lesions seen in children and adolescents, most often in the proximal humerus or femur.
  • They are typically asymptomatic until a pathological fracture occurs.
  • Radiological hallmark: Fallen fragment sign - a cortical bone fragment settles to the bottom of the cyst following fracture, indicating an empty cystic cavity.
  • Treatment is usually conservative with sling immobilisation unless the lesion is large or recurrent.

Explanation of other options:

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option A): Expansile, blood-filled lesion with fluid-fluid levels on imaging; lacks fallen fragment.

Enchondroma (Option C): Cartilaginous tumour, usually asymptomatic; no fallen fragment or fluid content.

Osteoid osteoma (Option D): Small diaphyseal lesion with central nidus and nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs.

Key Takeaway:

The 'fallen fragment sign' is a specific radiological feature of simple bone cysts, especially in children with pathologic fractures.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with persistent pain and swelling in the mid-thigh for the past month. His parents also report that he has been feeling feverish and lethargic. On examination, the thigh is tender with mild warmth and fullness. An X-ray reveals a diaphyseal lesion with a layered periosteal reaction and cortical destruction. Blood investigations show elevated WBC count, ESR, and LDH. What is the most likely age group in which this tumour has the highest incidence?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ewing sarcoma has its maximum incidence during the second decade of life (ages 10-20 years).

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a high-grade malignant bone tumour, most common in adolescents, especially between 10-20 years.
  • It shows a male predominance and is associated with a t(11;22) translocation (EWS-FLI1 fusion gene).
  • Diaphyseal involvement of long bones (femur, tibia) is characteristic.
  • Clinical signs include localised pain, swelling, and systemic features (fever, lethargy).
  • Radiology shows a destructive lesion with 'onion-skin' periosteal reaction and soft tissue mass.
  • It is MIC2 (CD99) positive, composed of small, round blue cells on histology.
  • Prognosis is worse with elevated ESR, WBC, and LDH, indicating systemic disease.
  • It is the most chemo and radiosensitive bone tumour.
  • Bone-to-bone metastasis is more common than in osteosarcoma; hence, bone scan is essential.

Key Takeaway:

Ewing sarcoma most frequently presents in the 2nd decade of life, particularly between 10 and 20 years of age.

choices.text: Surrounding sclerosis may be minimal or absent
There is often a lack of nocturnal pain that is responsive to aspirin
Histologically, osteoblastoma is similar to osteoid osteoma
The lesion is usually 5 mm to 10 mm in diameter

questions.text: All of the following statements are true concerning osteoblastomas except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteoblastomas are larger than 1.5 cm, distinguishing them from osteoid osteomas.

  • Osteoblastoma is a rare benign bone-forming tumour, typically occurring in children and young adults (ages 10-30).
  • There is a male preponderance (3:1).
  • Commonly affects the posterior elements of the vertebrae (~30-50%) and the diaphysis of long bones.
  • Lesion size usually exceeds 1.5 cm; this is the key radiological differentiator from osteoid osteoma, which is smaller.
  • Pain in osteoblastoma is often not characteristically nocturnal and less responsive to NSAIDs like aspirin. (Option B ruled out)
  • Histology resembles osteoid osteoma, but osteoblastoma shows more vascularity and lacks a sclerotic reaction. (Option C ruled out)
  • Surrounding sclerosis may be minimal or absent, unlike in osteoid osteoma (Option A ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Osteoblastomas are benign, expansile, >1.5 cm lesions with dull pain and minimal sclerosis, commonly affecting the spine.

questions.text: Which of the following is bone-forming malignant tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteosarcoma is the only malignant tumour that directly produces osteoid or immature bone matrix.

  • Bone-forming tumours are defined by their ability to produce osteoid or woven bone.
  • These can be benign or malignant:
    • Benign bone-forming tumours include:
      • Osteoid osteoma
      • Osteoblastoma
      • Enostosis (bone island)
      • Osteopoikilosis
      • Osteoma
    • Malignant bone-forming tumours are collectively termed osteosarcomas, which produce malignant osteoid.
  • Subtypes of osteosarcoma include:
    • Conventional osteosarcoma
    • Telangiectatic osteosarcoma
    • Low-grade central osteosarcoma

Explanation of other options:

Osteoid osteoma (Option A): A benign bone-forming tumour, usually <1.5 cm, with nocturnal pain.

Chondrosarcoma (Option C): A malignant tumour that forms cartilage, not bone.

Giant cell tumour (Option D): An osteolytic tumour with no osteoid production.

Key Takeaway:

Osteosarcoma is the only malignant primary bone tumour characterised by the formation of malignant osteoid.

choices.text: Thickened cartilage cap more than 1.5 cm

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered a sign of malignant transformation within an osteochondroma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fracture of an osteochondroma is usually the result of trauma and not considered a sign of malignant transformation.

Osteochondroma is a benign cartilage-capped bony projection, usually arising from the metaphysis.

Malignant transformation is rare (~1% in solitary, ~10% in multiple exostoses).

Features that should raise the possibility of malignant transformation can be remembered with the mnemonic GLAD PaST:

  • G:growth after skeletal maturity
  • L:lucency(new)(Option B ruled out)
  • A:additional scintigraphic activity
  • D:destruction(cortical)
  • P:pain after puberty(Option C ruled out)
  • a:and
  • S:soft tissue mass increased
  • T:thickened cartilage cap >1.5 cm(Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Fracture of an osteochondroma is trauma-related and not an indicator of malignant change; other signs like lucency, pain, and cartilage cap thickening are more reliable.

questions.text: What is shown on this single slice from a coronal PD-fat-saturated image from the right knee of a 15-year-old?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteochondroma presents as a bony exostosis with a cartilage cap, which appears hyperintense (bright) on fluid-sensitive MRI sequences such as PD-fat-saturated images.

  • Osteochondroma is the most common benign bone tumour in adolescents and young adults.
  • Not a true neoplasm-originates from an aberration of the growth plate.
  • Typically arises from the metaphyseal region, projecting away from the epiphysis.
  • On MRI:
    • Cartilage cap shows high signal on fluid-sensitive sequences (T2/PD-fat sat).
    • The bony stalk is continuous with the parent cortex and medullary cavity.
  • Occurs as a solitary lesion or in multiple hereditary exostoses.
  • Most lesions are painless unless they impinge on surrounding structures.

Explanation of other options:

Chondroblastoma (Option A): Typically epiphyseal, shows lower signal intensity; seen in younger patients but more localised to the epiphysis.

Chondrosarcoma (Option B): Usually occurs in older adults; cartilage cap thickening with soft tissue extension; destructive features on imaging.

Osteoblastoma (Option C): Rare, usually arises in the spine or diaphysis of long bones; does not have the classic exostotic morphology.

Key Takeaway:

Osteochondromas are bony outgrowths with cartilage caps showing high signal on MRI and are the most common benign tumours of bone in young individuals.

questions.text: What is the most common primary malignancy of the skeleton?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple myeloma is the most common primary malignant tumour of the skeleton, although metastases are the overall most frequent malignancy involving bone.

  • Bone malignancies can be:
    • Primary (arising from bone itself)
    • Secondary (metastatic) from other organs (most common overall)
  • Multiple myeloma is a hematologic malignancy arising from plasma cells and affects the bone marrow primarily.
  • It leads to multiple lytic lesions in bones, typically in the spine, skull, pelvis, and ribs.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumour of long bones, particularly in adolescents.
  • Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-forming tumour, more common in adults.
  • Osteochondroma is the most common benign tumour of the skeleton and is not a malignancy.

Explanation of other options:

Chondrosarcoma (Option B): Malignant but less common than multiple myeloma; affects older adults.

Osteochondroma (Option C): Most common benign bone tumour; not malignant.

Osteosarcoma (Option D): Most common primary malignant tumour of long bones, but multiple myeloma is more common overall among primary skeletal malignancies.

Key Takeaway:

Multiple myeloma is the most common primary malignancy of the skeleton, despite metastases being more common overall.

questions.text: Maffucci syndrome is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Maffucci syndrome is a rare, non-hereditary disorder characterised by multiple enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas.

  • It typically presents in childhood with:
    • Multiple enchondromas (benign cartilaginous tumours)
    • Coexisting vascular anomalies, usually cavernous hemangiomas
  • Most commonly affects hands and feet, causing bone deformities and limb asymmetry.
  • There is a high risk of malignant transformation, particularly to chondrosarcoma.
  • Differentiated from Ollier's disease, which involves multiple enchondromas without hemangiomas.
  • Enchondromas in Maffucci syndrome appear more cellular and proliferative than solitary ones.

Explanation of other options:

Hemangiomas and limb hyperplasia (Option B): Seen in Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome, not Maffucci.

Hemangiomas and precocious puberty (Option C): Feature of McCune-Albright syndrome, not Maffucci.

Hemangiomas and capillary malformation (Option D): More suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome or port-wine stains, not related to Maffucci.

Key Takeaway:

Maffucci syndrome combines multiple enchondromas with cavernous hemangiomas and has malignant potential.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with fibrous dysplasia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Harrison groove is seen in rickets, not in fibrous dysplasia.

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a benign developmental anomaly where normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue and immature woven bone.
  • Caused by a GNAS1 gene mutation, affecting Gs alpha protein signalling.
  • Common radiological and pathological features:
    • Rind sign - a well-defined radiolucent lesion with a thick sclerotic border (seen on X-ray)(Option A ruled out)
    • Chinese letter pattern - irregular woven bone trabeculae seen on histopathology(Option C ruled out)
    • Café-au-lait spots - common in polyostotic forms, especially in McCune-Albright syndrome. (Option D ruled out)
  • Harrison groove is not a feature-it's a horizontal depression along the chest wall due to rachitic changes from vitamin D deficiency.

Key Takeaway:

Harrison groove is seen in rickets, not in fibrous dysplasia.

questions.text: Management of ABC is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aneurysmal bone cysts require aggressive treatment involving extended curettage followed by bone grafting.

  • Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) is a benign, expansile, blood-filled bone lesion, often seen in children and adolescents.
  • Treatment involves:
    • Extended curettage - thorough removal of cyst lining and contents.
    • Adjuvant therapy - use of chemical agents (e.g., phenol, hydrogen peroxide) or physical agents (e.g., liquid nitrogen, bone cement) to reduce recurrence.
    • Bone grafting or graft substitutes to fill the cavity after curettage.
  • Less aggressive treatments like steroid injections are not effective for ABC.

Explanation of other options:

Aspiration and methylprednisolone injection (Option A): Used for Simple Bone Cysts (SBCs), not effective in ABC.

Curettage and cementing (Option C): Can be used in giant cell tumours, but bone grafting is preferred in ABC.

Aspiration and autologous bone grafting (Option D): Not standard; surgical curettage is mandatory in ABC for reducing recurrence.

Key Takeaway:

Extended curettage with bone grafting and adjuvants is the treatment of choice for aneurysmal bone cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence of chondrosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pelvis is the most frequent site involved in chondrosarcoma, followed by the femur.

  • Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-forming tumour that often retains its cartilaginous matrix.
  • Occurs commonly in men during the 4th-5th decades.
  • Common sites (in descending order):
    • Pelvis
    • Femur
    • Humerus
    • Ribs
    • Shoulder girdle
  • It typically involves the metaphysis or diaphysis of long bones.
  • Symptoms: Gradual pain and swelling or an enlarging mass.
  • Radiological signs:
    • Expansile radiolucent lesion in the medullary cavity
    • Endosteal scalloping
    • Characteristic punctate/comma-shaped or "popcorn" calcifications
  • Treatment of choice: Wide surgical excision (radiotherapy/chemotherapy not effective)

Key Takeaway:

Chondrosarcoma most commonly affects the pelvis and is managed surgically due to its resistance to chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a symmetric, expansile cystic lesion in the proximal humerus. All of the following can be done for his treatment except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Radiotherapy is not indicated in the management of solitary bone cysts due to the risk of radiation-induced sarcoma.

  • Solitary bone cyst (unicameral bone cyst) is a benign, fluid-filled, centrally located cyst, most commonly found in the proximal humerus (50-60%), followed by the femur.
  • Most common in boys aged 5-15 years.
  • It often presents asymptomatically or with a pathological fracture after trivial trauma.
  • Radiographic findings: Centrally located metaphyseal radiolucency with mild expansion.
  • Treatment options include:
    • Curettage and bone grafting
    • Intralesional methylprednisolone injection
    • Intralesional sclerosing agents (e.g., Ethibloc)
    • Percutaneous decompression using cannulated screws
  • Radiotherapy is contraindicated due to long-term risks, especially in pediatric patients.

Explanation of other options:

Curettage (Option A): A common surgical approach to remove the cyst lining and promote healing.

Intralesional steroids (Option B): Reduce cyst activity and promote resolution; widely used in children.

Intralesional sclerosing agents (Option C): Alternative to steroids; cause fibrosis and cyst collapse.

Key Takeaway:

Solitary bone cyst is managed conservatively or with minor procedures; radiotherapy is avoided due to malignancy risk.

choices.text: Multiple myeloma is seen after 55 years age
Osteosarcoma is seen in the 4th decade
Chondrosarcoma is seen in the 1st decade
Osteoclastoma is seen in the 5th decade

questions.text: Which of the following is true
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple myeloma typically affects elderly individuals and is most often diagnosed after the age of 55.

  • Bone tumours have characteristic age distributions that assist in diagnosis:
    • Osteosarcoma → Commonly seen in 2nd decade (10-20 years)(Option B ruled out)
    • Chondrosarcoma → Occurs in 4th to 5th decades(Option C ruled out)
    • Giant Cell Tumor (Osteoclastoma) → Seen in the 3rd to 4th decades(Option D ruled out)
    • Multiple Myeloma → Occurs after 55 years; most common primary malignant bone tumour in adults.

Key Takeaway:

Age of presentation is an important clue in differentiating bone tumours; multiple myeloma most commonly occurs after 55 years of age.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with back pain. CT showed an expansile lytic lesion in the transverse process of the vertebra. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An expansile, lytic lesion involving the transverse process in an adolescent is most characteristic of an aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC).

  • ABC is a benign, expansile, blood-filled bone lesion that frequently affects the posterior elements of the spine, including transverse processes.
  • Most common in children and adolescents, especially between 10-20 years.
  • Radiographically presents as a purely lytic, expansile, often eccentric lesion with a "blow-out" appearance.
  • CT helps to define the extent of cortical breach and location (here, the transverse process).
  • Osteoblastoma can also occur in posterior elements, but typically shows a sclerotic nidus with surrounding sclerosis rather than being purely lytic (Option A ruled out)
  • Osteosarcoma rarely involves the spine and typically affects the metaphysis of long bones (Option C ruled out)
  • Metastases are rare in this age group and typically involve vertebral bodies and pedicles, not transverse processes (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Aneurysmal bone cyst is the most likely diagnosis for an expansile lytic lesion in the transverse process of the vertebra in a 15-year-old.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with an expansile lytic lesion in the proximal humerus. X-ray shows a cortical fragment lying in the cavity of the lesion. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a cortical fragment lying dependently within the cystic cavity on X-ray is diagnostic of a "fallen fragment sign", which is pathognomonic for a Simple Bone Cyst (SBC).

  • SBC is a benign, non-neoplastic, fluid-filled lesion most commonly affecting the proximal humerus and femur in children aged 5-15 years.
  • The fallen fragment sign occurs when a pathological fracture through the thinned cortex allows a fragment to fall dependently into the cyst cavity, confirming its fluid-filled nature.
  • SBCs are often centrally located in the metaphysis and discovered incidentally or after fracture.
  • The sign distinguishes SBC from other lytic lesions like ABC, which are eccentric and septated, and do not show this sign.

Explanation of other options:

ABC (Option B): Eccentric lesion with blood-filled spaces; no fallen fragment sign.

GCT (Option C): Occurs after skeletal maturity, typically in the epiphysis of long bones.

Enchondroma (Option D): Cartilaginous tumour, usually in small bones of the hands and feet; lacks fallen fragment sign.

Key Takeaway:

The fallen fragment sign is diagnostic of Simple Bone Cyst, especially in the proximal humerus of a child.

questions.text: Chondrosarcoma can develop in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Maffucci syndrome is characterised by multiple enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas, and has a near 100% risk of malignant transformation, often into chondrosarcoma.

  • Chondrosarcoma can arise secondarily from benign cartilage tumours like enchondromas.
  • Maffucci syndrome is the only condition among the options that features multiple enchondromas, which are predisposed to chondrosarcoma.
  • Radiologically, phleboliths may be seen within soft tissue angiomas.
  • Malignant transformation typically occurs in adulthood, and regular follow-up is recommended.
  • Jaffe Campanacci syndrome(Option C ruled out)
    • Multiple non-ossifying fibromas
  • Mazabraud syndrome(Option D ruled out)
    • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
    • Myxomas
  • McCune Albright syndrome(Option A ruled out)
    • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
    • Cafe au lait spots
    • Precocious puberty

Key Takeaway:

Among syndromic conditions, only Maffucci syndrome carries a high risk of developing chondrosarcoma due to multiple enchondromas.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with wrist pain and swelling. An X-ray of the wrist is shown below. Identify the lesion:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The radiograph shows an eccentric, expansile lytic lesion involving the epiphysis and extending into the metaphysis of the distal radius in a skeletally mature patient, classic for Giant Cell Tumour (GCT).

  • GCT typically occurs after physeal closure (i.e., in skeletally mature individuals).
  • Most common sites: distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius.
  • The classic "soap bubble appearance" (due to septations in the lesion) is seen.
  • The lesion is epiphyseal and often abuts the articular surface.
  • Though benign, GCT is locally aggressive and may recur.

Explanation of other options:

ABC (Option B): Commonly in younger patients; eccentric, expansile, but occurs in the metaphysis and shows fluid-fluid levels on MRI.

Osteomyelitis (Option C): Shows permeative lytic destruction with surrounding sclerosis and possible sequestrum formation.

Fibrous Cortical Defect (Option D): Seen in children; metaphyseal lesion, small, usually asymptomatic and located in the cortex.

Key Takeaway:

GCT presents after physeal closure with an epiphyseal soap-bubble lesion, often in the distal radius or around the knee.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with slowly progressing swelling in the middle third of his right leg. X-ray shows areas of radiolucency surrounded by sclerosis. Microscopy revealed epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is adamantinoma, a rare low-grade malignant tumour with a predilection for the tibial diaphysis and epithelial histology.

  • Adamantinoma occurs predominantly in adults aged 20-40 years, with a male preponderance.
  • Most common site: Diaphysis of the tibia (about 85% cases).
  • Presents as painless or mildly painful swelling over months to years.
  • Radiologically: Lytic lesion with well-defined radiolucent areas and surrounding sclerosis ("soap bubble" or "honeycomb" appearance).
  • Histologically: Biphasic tumour composed of epithelial cells in fibrous stroma, which is pathognomonic.
  • Differentiated from osteofibrous dysplasia, which lacks epithelial elements.
  • Treatment: Wide resection due to the risk of local recurrence and rare metastasis.

Explanation of other options:

Osteofibrous dysplasia (Option B): Occurs in children; similar radiology but lacks epithelial cells on biopsy.

Osteosarcoma (Option C): More aggressive; metaphyseal location with sunburst periosteal reaction.

Osteoclastoma (Option D): Typically epiphyseal in skeletally mature individuals; histology shows multinucleated giant cells.

Key Takeaway:

Adamantinoma typically affects the diaphysis of the tibia in adults and shows epithelial cells within fibrous stroma on biopsy.

questions.text: Which is the most common radiation-induced tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteosarcoma is the most common malignant tumour induced by prior radiation therapy, typically referred to as secondary osteosarcoma.

  • Secondary osteosarcomas arise in previously irradiated bone, usually years after exposure to radiation.
  • These tumours are aggressive, high-grade, and have a worse prognosis than primary osteosarcoma.
  • The risk of radiation-induced osteosarcoma increases with higher doses of radiation and younger age at exposure
  • Latency period: Typically 5-10 years post-radiation.
  • Other rare radiation-induced tumours include fibrosarcoma and chondrosarcoma, but osteosarcoma remains the most frequent.
  • The most common radiation-induced benign tumour is osteochondroma.

Explanation of other options:

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B): Not known to be associated with prior radiation exposure.

Multiple myeloma (Option C): Is a haematological malignancy, not classically induced by radiation.

Chondrosarcoma (Option D): Rarely occurs due to radiation, but not the most common.

Key Takeaway:

Osteosarcoma is the most common malignant bone tumour associated with prior radiation exposure.

questions.text: The T 10 protocol for the treatment of osteosarcoma includes all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Etoposide is not part of the classical T-10 protocol used in osteosarcoma treatment.

  • The T-10 protocol was one of the earliest chemotherapy regimens developed for osteosarcoma.
  • It includes:
    • High-dose Methotrexate (MTX) with leucovorin rescue
    • Bleomycin
    • Dactinomycin (Actinomycin D)
    • Doxorubicin (Adriamycin)
    • Cyclophosphamide
  • Etoposide is not part of this protocol, although it may be included in other regimens or protocols for sarcomas.

Explanation of other options:

Methotrexate (Option B): A cornerstone drug in osteosarcoma regimens; included in T-10.

Bleomycin (Option C): Part of T-10; has pulmonary toxicity as a limiting side effect.

Doxorubicin (Option D): An anthracycline, central to most osteosarcoma chemotherapy protocols.

Key Takeaway:

Etoposide is not included in the T-10 protocol for osteosarcoma; it is seen in other sarcoma regimens.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with an expansile lesion in the distal femoral metaphysis. The lesion shows endosteal scalloping and punctate calcification. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endosteal scalloping with punctate calcification in a metaphyseal lesion of a middle-aged adult is characteristic of chondrosarcoma.

  • Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-forming tumour most commonly seen between the ages of 40-60 years.
  • The distal femoral metaphysis is a typical location for central chondrosarcomas.
  • Radiographic features include:
    • Endosteal scalloping (erosion of inner cortex)
    • Punctate, comma-shaped or "popcorn" calcifications within the lesion
    • Often central in location within the bone.
  • These features help distinguish it from other bone lesions of similar appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Chondroblastoma (Option A): Epiphyseal lesion, seen in adolescents and young adults.

Osteosarcoma (Option C): Usually arises in the metaphysis of long bones but occurs in the 2nd decade; has sunburst pattern or Codman's triangle.

Metastasis (Option D): Common in the elderly; typically shows lytic or blastic lesions, without endosteal scalloping or cartilage calcification.

Key Takeaway:

In a middle-aged adult, a metaphyseal lesion with endosteal scalloping and popcorn calcification strongly suggests chondrosarcoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the X-ray feature of fibrous bone tumours?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

"Ground glass appearance" is the classical radiographic hallmark of fibrous bone tumours, particularly fibrous dysplasia.

  • Fibrous tumours such as fibrous dysplasia exhibit a homogeneous, hazy "ground-glass" matrix on X-rays due to replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue.
  • This appearance results from the uniform fine trabeculation within the lesion.
  • It is often seen in the diaphyseal or metaphyseal region of long bones or in craniofacial bones.

Key Takeaway:

Ground glass appearance on X-ray is pathognomonic of fibrous bone tumours like fibrous dysplasia.
